header.title: Tarosophist International - Autumn 2009 Vol.1 Iss. 4 (Thoth Deck Annual Special Issue)
header.category: Western Esotericism, Tarot, Occultism, Thelema, Qabalah, Egyptian Mythology

central_thesis: This special issue of Tarosophist International provides a multi-faceted and in-depth exploration of the Thoth Tarot deck, covering its historical creation, esoteric foundations rooted in Thelema, Qabalah, and Egyptian mythology, various printing histories, and practical applications, offering diverse perspectives from leading experts to enhance understanding and operative use of the deck.

structure_content.summary: Introduces the Thoth deck as a 'Magical Atlas' created by Aleister Crowley and Lady Frieda Harris over five years, detailing its exhibition history and significance as a unique synthesis of magical teachings that merits rediscovery and further exploration into its mysteries.

Discusses the ethics and practicalities of professional Tarot reading, advocating for fair financial compensation for services rendered, and the importance of selectively donating skills. It also touches on the disruptive nature of monetary exchange in a reading.

Presents a chronological overview of Crowley's life, highlighting key publications, magical initiations, and significant geographical locations. It emphasizes the relatively late conception and execution of the Thoth deck within his magical career, making it a synthesis of his life's learning.

Offers guidance on approaching and learning the Thoth deck, stressing the importance of intuition, connecting with the collective unconscious, employing Jungian approaches, and integrating Kabbalah and Astrology. It emphasizes the deck's balance, beauty, and multi-layered nature, which allows for direct and taboo-free readings.

structure_content.chapter_title: Care & Feeding of Your Thoth Deck
structure_content.summary: Provides practical advice for interacting with and studying the Thoth deck, including recommendations for deck selection, proper storage, initial contemplation of the cards, understanding Crowley's Court Card changes, and a comprehensive list of essential background reading on Elemental Dignities, Kabbalah, Hebrew letters, and Egyptian Mythology.

Examines the Thoth Tarot's unique position within the Western Hermetic tradition. It details the historical influences of Etteilla and Court de Gébelin, the Golden Dawn's resequencing of Major Arcana and Hebrew letter attributions, and Crowley's specific innovations in card names (e.g., Magus, Adjustment, Art, The Aeon, Lust) and the 'Double Loop in the Zodiac' concept for astrological correspondences.

Analyzes Crowley's extensive intellectual and spiritual background, which informs *The Book of Thoth*. It presents a categorized reading list from *Magick in Theory and Practice*, covering Western philosophy, Hinduism, Alchemy, and Hermeticism, as essential preparatory study for understanding the complex layers of the Thoth deck.

structure_content.chapter_title: The (Printer's) Devil is in the Details: A Printing History of the Book of Thoth Tarot Deck
structure_content.summary: Details the various printed versions of the Thoth Tarot deck from 1944 to 2008. It outlines monochrome printings, the first full-color editions (Llewellyn/Weiser), and subsequent AGMuller and U.S. Games editions, noting key differences in card size, borders, color fidelity, inclusion of extra cards (Unicursal Hexagram, Magician variants), and printing errors across different releases.

A 1994 article celebrating the 50th anniversary of *The Book of Thoth*. It contextualizes the collaborative creation of the deck by Crowley and Harris, highlighting its status as one of the first true esoteric Tarot decks and acknowledging the challenges of its publication amid wartime conditions.

Summarizes the printing evolution of the Thoth deck, from its 1944 limited edition to subsequent monochrome and color printings. It highlights the involvement of various publishers, recurring printing errors, and ongoing design modifications over five decades, underscoring the deck's journey to faithful reproduction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Life is No Brief Candle to Me
structure_content.summary: A personal narrative reflecting on themes of life, death, and self-discovery through a multi-card reading with the Thoth deck. The author explores the deck's directness in revealing profound truths, using specific cards (Ace of Swords, Princess of Cups, Prince of Disks, Six of Wands, Moon, Ten of Cups, Four of Disks, Emperor, Queen of Cups) to illuminate a transformative journey.

Discusses the correct pronunciation of 'Thoth' and the nature of ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs. It explains the lack of definitive ancient recordings and the evolution of scholarly transliterations, suggesting 'Toff' as the closest pronunciation. It also provides a brief reading list for further study of Hieroglyphs.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Hierology of the Thoth Deck
structure_content.summary: Explores the permeation of Egyptian gods and goddesses throughout the Thoth deck, both explicitly depicted and implicitly invoked in its 'hierology.' It details Crowley's appropriation and mutation of deities like Thoth, Ma'at, Nuit, Osiris, Isis, Horus, Set, Maut, Sebek, Khephra, and Anubis, and their symbolism on cards like The Fool and Fortune.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Temple of Thoth - a Gated Spread
structure_content.summary: Introduces a unique, multi-stage Tarot spread for the Thoth deck, structured as an immersive magical journey through an 'invisible Temple' informed by ancient Egyptian concepts of the afterlife. It outlines three progressive levels of divination, each requiring specific actions and contemplation over several days to forge a 'living contract' with the Tarot and commune with the deity Thoth.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Qabalah of the Nine Chambers
structure_content.summary: Explains the Aiq Beker system of Qabalistic numerical analysis, used to convert Hebrew letters to numerical equivalents for discerning hidden truths and creating sigils. It relates these 'nine chambers' to Tarot Trumps and concepts like Lifetime or Birth Cards, highlighting its use by figures like S.L. MacGregor Mathers.

Analyzes the Small Cards within the Qabalistic framework of the Tree of Life, particularly focusing on the 'ladder of small cards' (Wands, Cups, Swords, Disks). It highlights the unique significance of the Ten of Disks as the 'climax of the descent of Matter' and the 'hieroglyph of the cycle of regeneration,' representing the point of maximum crystallization and potential for renewal.

Explores the multifaceted nature of The Fool card, discussing its historical unnumbered status, its representation as a simpleton or Bodhisattva, its connection to 'zero' as complete potential and a realm beyond language, and its forward movement symbolizing action, risk-taking, and innocence as an initiatory aspect.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Alchemical Cards of the Thoth Deck
structure_content.summary: Examines alchemy as a core transformative process within the Thoth deck, relating the Major Arcana to alchemical stages. It focuses on The Lovers (Solve/analysis) and Art (Coagula/synthesis) cards as embodying the alchemical maxim 'Solve et coagula,' detailing their symbolic connections to the Tree of Life, dualities, and the creation of a 'Winged Orphic Egg' for new life.

Reviews various published guidebooks for the Thoth deck, assessing their adherence to Crowley's original intent, ease of understanding, and originality. It provides a 'Summary Scorecard' for each, evaluating works by authors such as Ziegler, Arrien, Wanless, Willis, Banzhaf & Theler, DuQuette, and Akron, with DuQuette's book receiving high recommendation.

key_concepts.definition: A Tarot deck designed by Aleister Crowley and painted by Lady Frieda Harris, synthesizing Western Esotericism, Thelema, Qabalah, Alchemy, and Egyptian mythology. It is characterized by complex symbolism and directness.
Aleister Crowley's spiritual philosophy, encapsulated by the axiom 'Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law.' It informs the cosmology and symbolism of the Thoth Tarot.
Aleister Crowley's comprehensive companion text to the Thoth Tarot deck, detailing its intricate symbolism, Qabalistic and astrological correspondences, and Thelemic interpretations of each card.

An esoteric system originating in Jewish mysticism, adopted and adapted in Western Esotericism. It involves complex attributions of Hebrew letters, numbers, planets, and elements to the Tree of Life, which forms a foundational structure for Tarot correspondences.

A late 19th and early 20th-century Hermetic magical order that significantly influenced Aleister Crowley and Western Esotericism. It developed a comprehensive system of Tarot correspondences, including resequencing Major Arcana and attributing Hebrew letters, planets, and zodiac signs.

A central concept in Crowley's Thelema, referring to a new spiritual age initiated in 1904, characterized by individualism and self-realization, succeeding the 'Aeon of Osiris' (Christianity) and preceding the 'Aeon of Isis'.

A key alchemical maxim meaning 'dissolve and coagulate.' In the Thoth Tarot, it is embodied by The Lovers card (Solve, representing analysis and dissolution of contraries) and the Art card (Coagula, representing synthesis and recombination).

A unique, multi-stage Tarot reading method developed by Marcus Katz for the Thoth deck. It is designed as an immersive magical journey through an 'invisible Temple' over several days, requiring the practitioner to perform real-world actions and contemplation based on drawn cards to progress through distinct 'gates'.

The ancient Egyptian writing system, whose symbols and associated deities (like Thoth) are integral to the conceptual and visual foundation of the Thoth Tarot deck. The text discusses the scholarly understanding and pronunciation challenges of these ancient terms.

A system of Tarot interpretation used in the Thoth Tarot (derived from Golden Dawn tradition) where the meaning of a card is influenced by the elemental qualities of adjacent cards, rather than by reversals. This system is seen as key to understanding the cards' interactions.

A Qabalistic system, also known as 'The Qabalah of Nine Chambers,' for converting Hebrew letters to numerical equivalents by grouping them in a specific grid. Used for word analysis, creating sigils, and discerning hidden truths, it relates to Tarot Trumps and personal destiny calculations.

practical_system.description: The primary practical system presented is the 'Temple of Thoth - a Gated Spread,' a unique, multi-stage Tarot reading method designed for the Thoth deck. It conceptualizes the reading as an immersive, week-long magical journey through an 'invisible Temple' that mirrors ancient Egyptian temple structures and the processes of the afterlife. This system moves beyond single-session divination, requiring the practitioner to engage in specific actions, contemplation, and real-world 'fulfillment' of card conditions over several days before advancing to subsequent stages. It is framed as a 'living contract' with the Tarot, culminating in a direct communion with the deity Thoth, the deck's tutelary figure, to receive guidance for one's True Will.
tools: Kyphi incense (optional, specifically Katlyn’s incense from Mermade Magical Arts is mentioned)
Evocative music (e.g., 'Hymn for the Sunrise' by Ali Jihad Racy from 'Ancient Egypt')
Images or representations of appropriate Egyptian deities (optional, for visualization)
A dedicated wooden box and cloth for storing the Thoth deck (recommended for care and professionalism)

Reference texts for background study: Aleister Crowley's 'Book of Thoth', Liz Hazel's 'Tarot Decoded' (for Elemental Dignities & Astrological Correspondence), Dion Fortune's 'The Mystical Qabalah', Israel Regardie's 'A Garden of Pomegranates', and various online resources for Kabbalah, Hebrew letters, and Egyptian Mythology (e.g., 'www.digital-brilliance.com/kab', 'www.magickaschool.com', 'www.kabbalahcourse.com', 'www.egyptianmyths.net').
rituals: Day One: 'The Measure of Ma’at and The Heart’s Sacrifice' - A two-card reading for identifying actions and sacrifices required to meet Ma'at's measure, with a three-day period for fulfillment. Includes optional Solar Adoration (Liber Resh) and 'Entering the Temple of the World' visualization.

Day Four: 'Honouring the Living King and Passing the Fields of Iaru' - A two-card reading to understand one's essential self and the path to align with True Will, with a two-day period for decisive action and behavioral change.

Day Five: 'Choosing the Barque and Opening the Gates of Heaven' - A selection from three cards representing the Barques of Khons, Isis, or Ra, each posing a specific question ('What service must I offer,' 'What must I learn,' 'What shall I create'). The chosen card is contemplated for two days, signifying a passage into a new sense of self.
Day Seven: 'Entering the Naos' - A final two-card reading to commune with Thoth, asking 'What is your Word?' and 'How Shall I utter it?', signifying the direct reception of divine guidance.

relevant_quotes.text: Tarosophy, n. Conflation of Tarot (from It., triumph?) + Sophia (from G. Σoφíα, wisdom). Meaning lit. 'the wisdom of tarot'. Referred specifically to the living (divine) wisdom of the art and science of Tarot as practised by Tarosophists.
When wealth accumulates beyond a certain point, it must either become completely inert and cease to be wealth, or call in the aid of intelligence to use it rightly.
The Lovers (VI) and Art (Temperance, XIV) are 'so complementary they cannot be studied separately' (p. 84, Book of Thoth).
One must constantly keep in mind the bivalence of every symbol … it is the simplest test of initiation.
The High Priestess … is, in short, a symbol of the highest Initiation.
Of the Sun (XIX) … 'this is one of the simplest of the cards' (p. 113, Book of Thoth).
She [Queen of Cups] is the perfect agent and patient, able to receive and transmit everything without herself being affected thereby.
In the psychopathology of The Path, this card [8 of Cups] is the German Measles of Christian Mysticism.
It is the Formula of the Princess, the mode of fulfillment of the Great Work.
On the Fool (0) … 'In the initiated symbolism, the act of devouring is the equivalent of initiation'.
These twenty-two cards acquire a personality of their own: a very curious personality.

critical_analysis.relevance: This magazine issue is exceptionally relevant for deep study of the Thoth Tarot, offering an unparalleled collection of expert articles that cover its genesis, esoteric underpinnings, practical applications, and complex publication history. It provides critical insight into Crowley's motivations, Harris's artistic execution, and the deck's integration of various magical traditions. The content serves as a crucial resource for understanding the Thoth deck's place in Western Esotericism and its operative potential, going beyond superficial interpretations to delve into its technical and philosophical depth.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience consists primarily of advanced Tarot practitioners, academic researchers in Western Esotericism and occultism, students of Thelema and Qabalah, and serious collectors of Tarot decks. The technical language, in-depth historical analysis, and discussion of operative magical systems assume a foundational knowledge of esoteric concepts. While some articles offer practical reading advice, the overall tone and content are geared towards those seeking a rigorous, scholarly, and practical understanding of the Thoth Tarot's magical and philosophical framework.
